hero.title: For ocean-friendly travel
hero.subtitle: Our mission: help every traveler make choices that protect the ocean, its wildlife and local communities.

about.title: What GuardianMap does
about.text: GuardianMap highlights truly responsible marine activities, promotes those with official labels, and co-creates ethical tours with committed local agencies. Awareness is also at the core of our work through ocean-focused articles, strengthening collective consciousness for nature-respectful tourism.

activities.title: Responsible activities
activities.text: Dive centers, boat trips and low-impact experiences: eco-briefings, viewing distances, wildlife respect, and labeled partners whenever possible.

circuits.alt: Ethical tours co-built with local agencies
circuits.title: Ethical tours
circuits.text: Itineraries co-built with local agencies: responsible stays, small groups, and activities aligned with ecosystem protection.

blog.title: Awareness & Blog
blog.text: Good practices, labels, sensitive species‚Ä¶ Our blog helps understand real impact and adopt ocean-friendly habits.

hero.title: Activities
hero.line1: Each activity must have an official label awarded by governments or NGOs.
hero.line2: If it is not certified, it is not on GuardianMap.

criteria.title: Clear and rigorous criteria
criteria.text: Every dive center, boat trip, or marine activity must hold an official certification issued by governments or NGOs.
criteria.badge: If it‚Äôs not <c>certified</c>, it‚Äôs not on <c>GuardianMap</c>.

diving.title: Diving
diving.text: Centers applying recognized standards: boat management, responsible anchoring, coral protection and diver awareness. These operators are often labelled to minimize impact on marine ecosystems.

observation.title: Marine wildlife watching
observation.text: Learn how to observe marine wildlife while respecting their environment. Through responsible practices and certified operators, you can enjoy unique encounters without disturbing ecosystems.

filters.title: Which animal?
filters.hint: Click again on a card to show all animals.

observation.threatsIntroLine1: You might wonder how boat trips to watch whales, dolphins and other marine animals can be dangerous for them.

proximity.title: Excessive proximity
proximity.text: Collisions, propeller cuts, animals being surrounded or forced to change their route.

noise.title: Underwater noise
noise.text: Engines and repeated passages disturb communication, orientation and increase stress for cetaceans.

feeding.title: Feeding & over-frequentation
feeding.text: Dependence on humans, behaviour changes, chronic stress and degraded habitats.

observation.highlight: Choosing <blue>certified and trained operators</blue> helps <blue>reduce these impacts</blue> and lets animals keep the freedom to decide whether or not to interact.

greenfins.title: Green Fins
greenfins.text: International framework supported by the UN: boat management, responsible anchoring, coral protection.

blueflag.title: Blue Flag
blueflag.text: Environmental label for beaches and marinas: water quality, waste management, environmental education.

wca.title: World Cetacean Alliance
wca.text: Leading global label for ethical cetacean watching.

explain.point3: Authentic experiences away from mass tourism

intro.title: Good tourists aren‚Äôt born, they‚Äôre made
intro.text: Here we inform, raise awareness and share: good practices to adopt, bad habits to drop. Tourism can protect‚Ä¶ or destroy.

ws.title: Whale sharks: when the dream turns dangerous
ws.excerpt: Who hasn‚Äôt dreamed of seeing a whale shark? This gentle giant fascinates‚Ä¶

oman.aria: Read the Oman article (Daymaniyat, turtles, reef sharks)
oman.alt: Oman: Daymaniyat Islands, turtles and reef sharks
oman.title: Oman: protect, be patient‚Ä¶ and live magical encounters
oman.excerpt: A country that truly cares for marine life: regulated turtle access, protected Daymaniyat sites, no shark feeding‚Ä¶ Here, we observe gently and embrace the unexpected.

oman.title: Oman: protect, be patient‚Ä¶ and live magical encounters
oman.subtitle: An exemplary country: regulated turtle access, protected Daymaniyat Islands, natural encounters without feeding.
oman.heroAlt: Oman: Daymaniyat Islands, turtles, reef sharks
oman.p1: If there is a destination where true respect for wildlife is felt, it‚Äôs Oman. Encounters happen on nature‚Äôs terms. Authorities actively protect sea turtles and coastal ecosystems; visitors are invited to slow down ‚Äî for better encounters.
oman.h2_turtles: Sea turtles: regulated access for their peace
oman.p2: To watch turtles you must pay an access fee ‚Äî funding protection and monitoring. During nesting season, some beaches/islands are closed to tourists to avoid disturbing nesting or hatchlings. Result: less stress and preserved natural behaviour.
oman.h2_daymaniyat: Daymaniyat Islands: reef sharks‚Ä¶ without feeding
oman.p3: Around the Daymaniyat Islands you may meet reef sharks in a 100% natural setting: they are not fed. Boats keep their distance; you enter the water and swim to viewing zones. Sometimes you must be patient ‚Äî which is good: it prevents imbalance and makes the moment even more magical.
oman.h2_philosophy: A simple philosophy: see without disturbing
oman.li2: Respect distances and limit group sizes when needed.
oman.li3: Clear briefings and local guides who know the sites.
oman.quote: In Oman, patience is a virtue: the show is natural, unpredictable ‚Äî and unforgettable.

ws.title: Whale sharks: fragile beauty, shared responsibility
ws.subtitle: Why encounters must remain natural and how to observe without harm.
ws.heroAlt: Whale shark observed in its natural habitat
ws.intro_p1: In the vast blue of our oceans lives a gentle giant: the whale shark (Rhincodon typus).
ws.intro_p2: With its 12-meter length, a huge mouth filtering plankton, and a star-speckled back, it fascinates divers worldwide. Despite its size, this shark is harmless to humans: it feeds on micro-organisms, moves slowly, and embodies serenity.
ws.intro_p3: But this beauty,almost mythical, is also what puts it at risk today.
ws.attraction_p1: In several regions (Philippines, Mexico, Maldives, Mozambique, Thailand), the whale shark has become a true attraction. Some operators promise a ‚Äú100% chance‚Äù of seeing one.
ws.attraction_p2: Yet no encounter in the wild can ever be guaranteed. When a company claims certainty, it almost always means the animals are artificially fed to ensure their presence.
ws.attraction_p3: This practice, sadly widespread, has serious long-term consequences on behavior and health.
ws.carouselCaption: Glances of whale sharks in different regions (always follow local rules and guidelines).
ws.derives_intro: Feeding whale sharks is not benign. In the short term, it looks harmless: the animal approaches, visitors leave amazed. In the long term, the impacts are damaging:
ws.derives_li1: Behavioral disruption: dependence on feeding hotspots.
ws.derives_li2: Reduced migration: altered routes impacting reproduction and population health.
ws.derives_li3: Frequent injuries: propeller strikes or repeated contact with visitors.
ws.derives_li4: Health risks: unsuitable food disturbing metabolism.
ws.derives_outro: What starts as good intentions can end up harming their natural balance.
ws.practices_li1: Choose eco-certified operators (e.g., Green Fins or PADI Eco Center) or tours that do not guarantee a sighting.
ws.practices_li2: Never touch or feed the animal.
ws.practices_li3: Respect distances: at least 3‚Äì4 m from the head and 6 m from the tail.
ws.practices_li4: Limit the number of divers/boats present at the same time.
ws.practices_li6: Check natural seasons/areas where whale sharks aggregate.
ws.practices_outro: A respectful encounter is authentic and rare and all the more magical.
ws.orgs_mmf: Marine Megafauna Foundation (MMF) : Mozambique-based; long-term monitoring, photo-ID, and outreach. marinemegafauna.org
ws.orgs_sos: Save Our Seas Foundation : funds scientific and educational projects on sharks and rays. saveourseas.com
ws.orgs_wildbook: Whale Shark Project (Wild Me / Wildbook for Whale Sharks) : a global platform using spot patterns for individual identification.
ws.conclusion_p1: The whale shark symbolizes the fragility of beauty. It reminds us that fascination should never turn into domination.
ws.conclusion_p2: Every photo, every dive, every encounter can be an act of respect or disturbance. The choice is ours.
ws.quote: Loving the ocean also means learning to protect it.
ws.cta: Find truly responsible dive centers here: guardianmap.com/plong√©e

wmd.title: World Maritime Day: why maritime matters to everyone
wmd.subtitle: An IMO/UN day highlighting shipping‚Äôs vital role, safety at sea and ocean protection.
wmd.p1: World Maritime Day was created by the International Maritime Organization (IMO). It is celebrated annually, usually on the last Thursday of September.
wmd.p2: Goals: highlight shipping‚Äôs importance ‚Äî 80‚Äì90% of trade moves by sea ‚Äî and recognize seafarers, while raising awareness on environment, safety and innovation.
wmd.p3: Each edition proposes a specific theme (pollution prevention, energy transition, digitalization, ship safety, etc.).

pj1.title: 1) Decarbonization in Singapore ‚Äî marine biofuel trials (GCMD)
pj1.text: In Singapore, the Global Centre for Maritime Decarbonisation (GCMD) ran real-world trials with biofuels (B20‚ÄìB30). Aims: cut GHGs and validate interoperability (fuel quality, engines, bunkering, performance).
pj1.b2: Impact: measured emission cuts on commercial routes.

pj2.title: 2) Underwater noise reduction ‚Äî IMO guidelines (GloNoise)
pj2.text: Underwater noise affects fish and marine mammals. GloNoise supports applying IMO guidelines: monitoring, design integration, and operational good practices.
pj2.b2: Impact: noise mitigation in biodiversity hotspots.

pj3.title: 3) Nigeria ‚Äî awareness against plastic pollution (NIMASA)
pj3.text: NIMASA ran local campaigns: schools, calls to cut single-use plastics, and promotion of sustainable opportunities tied to a healthy sea.
pj3.b1: Scope: coastal communities, schools, local authorities.

wmd.h2_why: Why talk about it on GuardianMap?
wmd.why1: Our coastal and diving activities rely on a healthy ocean.
wmd.why2: Cleaner, safer shipping lanes benefit biodiversity and coastal communities.
wmd.why3: Understanding these issues helps us travel better and support responsible operators.
wmd.quote: Protecting the ocean also means caring about how our goods move and those who make the sea economy run.

about.title: About us
about.subtitle: Behind GuardianMap are two ocean lovers who decided to act to protect what they cherish most: marine life.

thomas.name: Thomas
thomas.bio: An adventurer at heart and ocean lover, Thomas brings his energy and strong organisational spirit to turn GuardianMap into reality.

jade.name: Jade
jade.bio: A passionate diver and travel enthusiast, Jade brings her creativity and vision to build a more respectful way to explore our oceans.

why.title: Why did we create GuardianMap?
why.problem: Many travellers, with good intentions, don‚Äôt always know how to behave responsibly around the ocean. We dream of seeing marine beauty‚Ä¶ but sometimes, without realising it, we contribute to harming it.
why.solution: GuardianMap makes responsible marine travel easy by highlighting certified sustainable operators and inspiring travellers through education. Our goal: empower everyone to protect the ocean while exploring it.

hero.title: Activities
hero.subtitle: GuardianMap highlights responsible marine tourism: operators with strict best practices and, where possible, recognized certifications.

panel.gfNote: Note: these levels filter Green Fins centers only.

why.title: Why choose a certified center?
why.text1: Choosing a certified operator reduces the environmental impact of your trips and supports practices that protect marine ecosystems.

list.briefings: Clear briefings on viewing distances and good practices.
list.followup: Ongoing monitoring and improvement of environmental practices.

why.boxText: You vote with your wallet for committed operators while maximising your chances of seeing abundant, healthy marine life.

gf.title: What is Green Fins?
gf.text1: Green Fins (Reef-World Foundation & UNEP) supports dive and snorkel operators in adopting responsible practices: waste management, anchoring, group sizes, awareness-raising, and more.
gf.text2: The Gold, Silver, Bronze, Inactive and Digital levels reflect how committed operators are and how closely they follow best practices.

box.point3: Focused on the ocean and coral reefs

bf.title: What is Blue Flag?
bf.text1: Blue Flag recognises beaches, marinas and boats that meet strict criteria: water quality, waste management, safety, public information and environmental education.
bf.text2: The label is renewed every year based on regular inspections.
